title: Fast sync database size grows from 350 GB to 800 GB after the initial sync was completed
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `v1.10.3`
OS & Version: Linux

#### Expected behaviour

Chain database size being 400 GB at max.

#### Actual behaviour

The database size slowly but steadily grows from 350 GB to 800 GB (as shown on Etherscan).

Database growth after resync:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43043344/119005198-881d1000-b98f-11eb-8a6a-26138a061d94.png)

Database growth without resync:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43043344/119005428-bb5f9f00-b98f-11eb-85f1-f3892217f9d2.png)

According to Etherscan, the Geth DB size is almost twice as large as OpenEthereum. Something is definitely wrong here.

`du` output on the 580 GB node (first chart):

```
213G	geth/chaindata/ancient
531G	geth/chaindata/
```
What command/params are you running with?

Sorry, should have provided this information initially. Nothing that affects the database size. Only regular flags like `--http`, `--maxpeers`, `--datadir`, etc.

Perhaps Geth is not pruning something? It essentially acts as a full node with disabled state pruning, though, the state is being pruned.
I assume that Geth can be downloading additional data, which is not really required in this node's use case (it is a mining node). If this is true, is there a way to disable that?

It looks like it doesn't prune, yes, which can be a side-effect of 
- `gcmode=archive` 
- Low cache levels, which causes it to flush the in-memory data more often than if it had more memory.

During block processing, it says something about `dirty=20mb`, and whenever it flushes, it goes down to zero. So could you provide some logs (perhaps a few minutes) of block processing? And/or the startup logs where it determines the cache limits.

```
Allocated trie memory caches             clean=614.00MiB dirty=1024.00MiB
```

Cache size is left untouched. Should I have raised it?

> Cache size is left untouched. Should I have raised it?

Not necessarily, IMO. 

Could you also provide some logs from the block processing?

Here.

FYI, this node is running a bit customized version of Geth that accepts MEV bundles.


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43043344/119488281-a6518a00-bd5a-11eb-8a84-bc905ab7c39a.png)

Helped. Growth has indeed slowed down.

Interesting. I mean, it's not terribly surprising that more cache makes the pruning more efficient, but it seemed to me like your existing `1Gb` of dirty cache should have a better effect that it seemed to have. How large does `dirty=1022.53MiB` grow up to with the new setting?
Was `dirty=3.37GiB` 24 hours ago, and now it is `dirty=4.14GiB`.

> FYI, this node is running a bit customized version of Geth that accepts MEV bundles.

Perhaps the customized miner code is flawed and it pushes all bundles to disk afer running them? That would explain the blowup.

Bundles are not stored on the disk, only in the memory.

Primarily, only the code inside the `miner/` directory was modified, so it is highly unlikely that this issue occurs only on this fork.
Well, if the code in miner does a commit on the state then it's game over /shrug. I can't debug code I can't see.

Hmm, if the issue does indeed apply to our fork only - then apologies for wasting your time and opening an issue here.

The code in `miner` only makes changes via `core.ApplyTransaction(...)` to `w.current.state`, and several copies of it. Does it make disk writes?

As I said, I can't debug code I can't see :)

We don't see this blowup happening on our bootnodes and benchmarkers; and we haven't received reports from miners wrt to this issue. This makes me think the bug should be in your modifications.

If any of your code directly or indirectly calls `statedb.Commit`, then that might be the issue.

Btw, wrt the Etherscan chart, that's over the course of a year. Geth does not have disk pruning (ok, 1.10.0+ has based on snapshots, but you need to take you node offline for it), so if you contiguously run a Geth node, junk will slowly accumulate. It does not accumulate as fast as your node however, by 2 orders of magnitude.

The reason for the database not being pruned correctly is the change from
```go
const TriesInMemory = 128
```
to

```go
const TriesInMemory = 512
```

This was made to increase the state history on a fast node while not turning on archive mode by disabling gc via `--gcmode=archive` flag.

Apologies for opening an issue here. It was clearly a problem on our side.
